US shareholders own ZERO of the company. The ADS shares of Chinese companies are structured that way that they do NOT own any part of the company. So if Junko or Daqo decides to pull out of the US stock market they can do that with US shareholders getting ZERO. There is a great article about that on WSJ. I suggest you guys read it.

The most obvious reason to push this stock price down is to make a killing in China. Anyone who doesn't catch on to this, must be blind or naive. Daqo has proven that the Shanghai IPO's fetch a massive premium, and that in China, these companies get valued as their peers do (Trina, JA Solar, Tongwei, Xinte, etc.) By pushing the price as low as possible, any hedge fund (could be Morgan Stanley, too, since the STAR IPO is not only available to Chinese investors) that can get in on that IPO can buy up an ever larger percentage of Jinko for practically nothing, and make a fortune the first day this baby trades in STAR. As I already posted, if the Jinko price can be kept around $40-50, they'll have to sell 25% or more to get the $1B capital they are looking to get, leaving us US longs with less than 50% of the company, but without any gurantees that arbitraging will happen. (It's certainly not happening for DQ....) I'm ever more convinced of the fact that there are powerful hedge funds behind this to walk away with billions in a few months. A no brainer....

The DQ subsidiary IPO is amazing - 180% up in one day. The US ADR's should closely follow suit, but will they? It'll be the most exciting day today for JKS long holders to see how the US investors react to this IPO. If they don't move the DQ price up to a similar level, the subsidiary could potentially buy out the parent company and say goodbye to the western markets forever.

Company just announced details of the IPO filing….no surprises. They want to raise around $800 million to $1 billion and the number of shares they have to sell will obviously depend on the stock price.Currently, JKS trades at one-third the EBITDA multiple of its peers in China…. So if we equalize the EBITDA multiple, the stock should be at $120 and they will need to sell only the equivalent of 8 million ADSs to raise their target of a billion.

JKS business is in a growing market. JKS is the market leader in it.Around 20 % market share.The growth rate for the next five years will be around 20-25 % yearly worldwide.JKS will participate at least on this level from sales point of view.JKS produce the solar panel with the highest efficiency in the market.There are several panels with a higher efficiency but only under laboratory conditions.Mass production of these panels is years away. Simply too expensive.JKS will be the market leader for many more years.Here in Germany the share of green electrical energy production is around 50 % in 2020.Mainly solar and wind energy. Other countries have to follow to reduce CO2 production.Expected 2021 EPS = around 6 $Expected 2022 EPS = around 7.5 - 8 $Fair P/E 2021 is 15-20. That means 90 - 120 $ share priceFair P/E 2022 is 15-20. That means 110 - 160 $ share price.Basically a still perfect buying oportunity.But there is only one thing to consider...It's a Chinese company...The daily action in stock volume is not normal.

What silence in August. Has given me time to do more research, and I was surprised that I hadn't noticed that Jinko's growth rate YoY Q1 20 to 21 was zero while Trina, JA Solar, LONGI, and Risen have had outstanding growth rates. The same is true for quarter over quarter growths for the whole past year. I'm starting to get nervous about Jinko's ability to compete with the Chinese traded players that have much better access to capital due to their far higher market valuations than Jinko has in the US. The US has managed to really throttle Jinko to the brink of bankruptcy where I'm wondering if they will survive 5 years down the road.... The STAR listing may be coming too little too late.... Hopefully I'm not really seeing the next Yingli or Suntech Power in the making....

Jinko’s listing on the STAR market is likely to happen in the next few months, earlier than the 2022 that was previously expected. The valuation is also likely to be 50% to 100% higher than the valuation in the US market. This will allow them to raise larger amounts of capital at much lower cost and even pay down some debt. This would be the mecahnism by which the price and valuation gap between US and Chonese markets will narrow.

Focusing on the fourth quarter results, relative to consensus expectations, shipments and revenues were better and gross margin was also higher. So why are the results disappointing if you remove all the one time write-offs of obsolescence in plant and equipment and impairment in value of a solar project (which added $50 million to operating costs), and you eliminate all the “mark to market” noise created by the change in value of derivatives surrounding the convertible debt, then the item that stocks out like a very sore thumb in costs is SHIPPING. Yes the cost of shipping has more than doubled in the last few months and they were not able to pass it to their customers, perhaps for contractual reasons.But again, this is a short to medium term phenomenon, a legacy of the disruption caused by the pandemic.

Jinkosolar is a totally undervalued stock!Here are the facts:Jinkosolar is the world leader (number one in China, Middle East, Australia and Europe and number 2/3 in the US) in the solar module business. Furthermore, this company is also technology leader for monocrysaline PV modules. It was the first vertical integrated PV module producer in the world, which covers the whole process (wafer, cells, modules). Adding to this, the company is massivley expanding its business into new areas (they are one of the biggest solar project companies, e.g. they finalized currently the 1 billion US$ project in VAE in conneciton with EDF, which will lead to the sale of 4 Million modules in 2021) and into the battery energy storage. They started to sell it in December!). As China, Europe etc. are moving to renewables as well as the situation that more and more countries reach grid parity, the company still invests massivley into the expansion of the production facilites to cover the demand, which will lead to massiv growth in the near future. Furthermore, the massiv push of countries into the hydrogen economy will also lead to growth of the solar sector. The only useful hydrogen production will be "green hydrogen" produced by solar or wind. Adding to this, the PV producer market has already gone through a major consolidation. While companies like Sunedision, Solarworld or Q-Cells went bancrupt, the five biggest PV producer of the world already have a marketshare of around 70%. They will dominate the ASPs in the near future, which will be beneficial for the margins.This company is only 15 years old, but will make already 5 billion revenues in 2020 and grows by around 20% at the moment. They earn money; Ebitda positiv by around 700-750 million in 2020 and 150 mill net (before currency valuations). Even as the margins came under pressure due to some raw material shortages....this will be over in the coming months, as new solar glass and polysilicon facilities come online (refer to CEO of Daqo and Trina Solar). The stock valuation of Jinkosolar is ridicolous compared to hydrogen companies or some solar companies, like Sunpower (which will miss the future, except TOTAL will fully buy it!) or First Solar. If you would compare it to a PLUG POWER, Jinko should be traded by around 1.500 US$, while if you would take First Solar (which is smaller than Jinkosolar) into account, the company should be valued by around 250 US$.The stock increase of 120% in 2020 was ok, but I really look forward to 2021, especially since the IPO of the project daughter will also lead to an increase of the valuation. This company is already valued in the "road show" process by around 4 billion US$, which would be more of the 3 billion, which Jinko is traded at the moment. Totally long and bullish!

This strategic deal with Maersk, the world’s largest shipping company, is very important. Shipping costs are almost 6% of sales…. That is a very high number in any industry, more so for solar modules where gross margins have been pretty low to begin with….But the big story that is going to take the stock to $100 plus this year and over $500 in the next few years will be MARGIN improvement. Long term gross margins are heading up because industry is consolidating, technology transitions are more difficult and more capital intensive and the value proposition is already compelling versus fossil fuels.Reducing shipping costs as a percentage of sales is one more way to improve margins.

Some excellent news again with longterm agreement with Wacker. Just like Jinko did with Xinte (sourcing polysilicion in Mongolia instead of Xinjiang), they are now going to source a significant amount of polysilicon from US/German plants which will (theoretically) allow them to manufacture safely for US/European markets free of tariffs and supply chain woes.

How to raise the share price?The problem:Market capitalisation in USD:Longi: 65bnTongwei: 25bnJaSolar: 12bnTrina Solar: 8bnJinkosolar: 2bn The fastest and most efficient solution is laid out in the mail below to JKS Investors Relation.If you want to move the stock upwards you should send an mail to JKS instead of writing here...Dear Sir or Madam, JinkoSolar has a persisting low market valuation compared to its china listed peer group. This makes the company potentially vulnerable and poses an unnecessary threat to success. JinkoSolar announced to list Jiangxi Jinko at China STAR market to get better access to capital markets after enduring the complex listing procedure. Not the missing China listing is what is standing in the way to raise the Mcap, it is more the fact to be listed on NASDAQ where Chinese solar stocks have traditionally a detrimental existence. As long as the US are responsible for the fate of the share price of JKS there won´t be a sustainable base. JinkoSolar is listed in Germany as well and has a very enthusiastic supportive community which provides a trade volume of several hundred thousand shares on good days, more than enough given the actual free float. The daily trading of JKS stock always follows the same pattern which shows a positive trend until the US market opens the gates to the casino. Unfortunately there seems to be a long road until a china listing of the daughter company could provide some support for the JKS stock on NASDAQ - possibly. JKS´s Capex guidance for this year raises the question of an overloaden debt burden which itself suppresses the stock price and would lead to a very dilutive stock placement if necessary. This is a risk which a highly valued company (i.e. Longi) doesn´t have at all. The lack of this risk alone works like a bulletproof backstop for a plunging share price. JKS is currently in the opposite situation and exposed to any kind of price speculation. A hypothetical raise of 500mn USD capital by equity would mean in case of Longi an indiscernible dilution of less than 1%. To get the same amount of money, JKS had to issue additional 30% of its outstanding stock! This is a misfortune which can´t be compensated elsewhere. Therefore I would like to give you the advice to simply delist JKS from NASDAQ trading. This is no detrimental point for the company´s image. There are no big hurdles which would take time to realize this move. Any ADRs can easily be traded in Germany as well as in the US. The German TRADEGATE exchange is opened until the usual US closing. There is no timely extensive procedure of requirements to overcome. There is no costly redemption or conversion in the forefront. Even US customers of JKS´s solar products will certainly prefer a sound, well financed company which can offer competitive priced products instead of a company that sacrifices its edge to the notorious mispriced valuation on NASDAQ. When the announcement of this liberating shift is communicated reasonably there will rather be a sigh of relief than a meaningful share price dip and the bounce back of the JKS stock which is trading then mainly on TRADEGATE / Germany will be stellar - and based on a far more solid and predictable footing. There are many European green energy companies with far higher valuation thanks to their main listing in Germany. The market is by far big enough for any capital-requiring measures. There are a lot of influential german analysts in the financial media promoting JKS day by day to investors but any up-move to the stock price suffocates when NASDAQ opens. Most JKS investors - even in the US - would highly welcome to get rid of NASDAQ´s continuously bearish impact on "suspicious" Chinese stocks. The US bias towards China seems to be far from a turnaround and will further suppress JKS stock price, its company value and its refinancing abilities as long as the US listing keeps to be market making - irrespective of any achievements JKS provides.The fact that a high market capitalization itself accounts for the possible success of a company in today´s markets could be crucial for JKS to stay in the solar worlds´ well financed top tier. With respect to recent market developments in the solar industry as well as in the political environment and especially with respect to the financial markets´ stance to JKS, I would highly appreciate if you consider this remark seriously. I would appreciate your feedback. Kind regards,

I am almost back to even on JKS. I have solar panels on my house. They are REC N-Peak panels. Total cost was about $27k for 27-panels installed. Fed gov't paid $8,000, power company paid $6,000. I paid the remaining off in 1-year. My power bills are $26/month vs $250/month average before them. When the power company when with digital meters that are now 99.5% accurate, peoples bills went to $400+/month. The power company required it because the old analog meters were very inaccurate. People are screaming and shifting to solar. They missed out on all the incentives I got, but they don't care now. HOA's in our area are trying to stop the flood. HOA's are not permitted to block installation of solar panels and you don't even need their approval.

China is a capitalist dictatorship. They have almost nothing in common with the other "communist" countries I've read and heard about. Total wealth in China is rising faster than in most parts of the world. Worldwide total wealth is estimated at about $418 trillion (that's about $418 million million or $60,000 for every man, woman and child in the world on average, which we all know has nothing to do with reality, but oh well. As statistics go.) China is estimated to have about 18% of that total WW wealth and the US about 30%, but China's wealth almost tripled in the past 10 years while the US's doubled. A lot of that wealth is in stocks which could evaporate in a flash theoretically, but that's highly doubtful - neither in the US nor China will people be happy to see a big percentage of their "wealth" disappear. $45 trillion of $126 trillion or 36% is the portion of US wealth in NYSE/NASDAQ, while in China, its about $18 trillion of $75 trillion total wealth, or 24%. The days where "big boys" in NY or any other place control the value of these internationally linked stock markets are probably history, although they can do some damage to individual companies for a temporary period of time. Before the Chinese equity offering last year, the holding company owned around 85% of the operating subsidiary. That went down to 73% after the offering. Now, if they sell the maximum amount of shares to raise approximately $1 billion at around $50 per share, we the holders of parent company stock will end up owning around 55%.In that situation, the total enterprise value of the company will be about $4.5 billion of equity and debt net of cash of around $1.5 billion, so a total of $6 billion.For an enterprise value of $10 billion, the stock has to go up an additional $4 billion, ie., essentially double. Even doubling would put it at a price to EBITDA and price to revenues that is at a significant discount to its Chinese peers trading in the Chinese markets.

CFRA is entitled to their opinion about the future no matter how ill-informed. My own analysis suggests the next two years are going to be a period of sustained growth of at least 30% in unit shipments of modules, relatively stable pricing because of limited poly silicon supply and growing concentration of market share, and therefore IMPROVING gross margins which could exceed 20% by 2022. Also JKS is now a vertically integrated module maker which means they capture internally all the margin that goes to the wafer makers.As a result $5.00 in 2021 earnings is conservative, $6.00 is likely and $7.00 is possible.Similarly in 2022, $7.00 is conservative, $8.00 is likely, and $9.00 is possible.As this improving margin and earnings picture unfolds, I think the P/E multiple will expand as well. Stocks like ENPH and DQ have demonstrated that when margins expand, out of favor stocks with low multiples can experience MASSIVE multiple expansion. So a 20X multiple is definitely in JKS’ future.

Another thing that I didn't like at all about the Q1 report is the way they seemed to do an almost panic driven switch from just module production to selling wafers and cells without any explanation during the quarterly report. They were talking about gaining market share in module sales world-wide the past year, and all of a sudden, they're substantially reducing module production.... So much for gaining more market share in that space.
